question_text: One base of a trapezoid is $100$ units longer than the other base. The segment that joins the midpoints of the legs divides the trapezoid into two regions whose areas are in the ratio $2: 3$ . Let $x$ be the length of the segment joining the legs of the trapezoid that is parallel to the bases and that divides the trapezoid into two regions of equal area. Find the greatest integer that does not exceed $x^2/100$ .

Let the shorter base be $a$. We can let the longer base be $b = a + 100$, so that we have $b-a=100.$
The height of this trapezoid is given by $$h=\sqrt{\left(\frac{ab}{2} \right)^2+\left( \frac{(b-a)h}{2}\right)^2 }=\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{4}-\frac{(100h)^2}{16}},$$
so the area of this trapezoid is 
$$A = 100\cdot h\left(\frac{a+b}{2} \right)=50ah+25b(h-a).$$
If we let $y$ be the length of the median, then we know that $$y=\sqrt{\frac{(ab)^2}{4}-\left( \frac{(a-b)h}{2}\right)^2}= \sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2-2ab}{4}+\frac{100^2 h^2}{16}},$$so
$$A_y = 50y\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) = y(a+b) - 25b \cdot y.$$Now, note that $$\dfrac{A_x}{A_y}=\dfrac{x(x+a)}{y(x+a+b)},$$ and this area ratio must be equal to $2/3$, so
\begin{align*}
\dfrac{x(x+a)}{y(x+a+b)}&=\dfrac23\\
\dfrac{x^2+ax}{y(a+b)+25b}&=\dfrac23\\
\dfrac{a(3x-x^2)}{100h}+\dfrac{b(2x-2x^2)}{4h} &=\dfrac23\\
\Rightarrow \qquad 100h(3x-x^2)+b(2x-2x^2) & = \dfrac{8a(3x-x^2)}{3}
\end{align*}where we have used $$y=\sqrt{\frac{(ab)^2}{4}-\left(\frac{(a-b)h}{2}\right)^2}= \sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2-2ab}{4}+\frac{100^2 h^2}{16}},$$so
\[b= a+100,\quad h=\sqrt{\dfrac{a^2+(a+100)^2}{4}-\left(\dfrac{(a-a)(100)}{2}\right)^2}, \text{ and } y =\sqrt{\dfrac{a^2 + (a+100)^2-2a(a+100)}{4}+\dfrac{100^2 (ah)^2}{16}}.\]Since we can calculate $b$ and $h$, this gives us an equation in terms of only $a$. The first step is to find
\begin{align*}
\sqrt{\dfrac{(a+100)^2-a^2-200a}{4}-\left(\dfrac{100(a-h)}{2}\right)^2} & = \sqrt{\dfrac{-60000 a + 25,000 a^2-5000,000 a^2}{16}}\\
&= 50|ah|
\end{align*}
so that we know $h=\pm 5a$. Substituting this into our first equation, we have that \begin{align*}
100a(3x-x^2) + (a+100)(2x-2x^2) & = \dfrac{8a(3x-x^2)}{3}\\
\Rightarrow \qquad 300x - 1000 x^2 + 2ax -200x +400x -400x^2&= 8ax -\dfrac{8x^2 a}{3} \\
\end{align*}
So,
$$-1200x^2+2ax+(600a)&=0.$$Using the quadratic formula, this means that
$$x=\dfrac{-2a \pm \sqrt{4a^2 - 4(-1200) (600a)}}{-2400} = \dfrac{3a}{12}-\dfrac{a}{60}\sqrt{160(300 a)}=\dfrac{a(5-\sqrt{480a})}{60}.$$
However, since $x$ cannot be negative, we must have that
$$x=\dfrac{a(5+\sqrt{480a})}{60},$$so 
\begin{align*}
\dfrac{x^2}{100}&= \dfrac{(a)(25+10\sqrt{480 a} + 480a)}{3600}\\
&= \dfrac{(a) (25+48\sqrt{3} + 20a)}{3600}.
\end{align*}
The greatest integer that does not exceed this is $44$, and we have $$x^2 = \left(\dfrac{(5+\sqrt{480a})}{60}\right)^2\cdot (100).$$
